sub_topic: Calculation of entropy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
What is the entropy change for the combustion of methane (CH4) at standard conditions (298K and 1 atm)? The balanced chemical equation for the reaction is:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)

Given the standard molar entropy values for the reactants and products:

S(CH4) = 186.3 J/K·mol

S(O2) = 205.0 J/K·mol

S(CO2) = 213.6 J/K·mol

S(H2O) = 70.0 J/K·mol
message_2:
To calculate the entropy change (ΔS) for the combustion of methane, we can use the following equation:

ΔS = ΣnS(products) - ΣnS(reactants)

where n is the stoichiometric coefficient and S is the standard molar entropy.

For the products:

ΔS(products) = 1 * S(CO2) + 2 * S(H2O) = 1 * 213.6 J/K·mol + 2 * 70.0 J/K·mol = 213.6 + 140.0 = 353.6 J/K·mol

For the reactants:

ΔS(reactants) = 1 * S(CH4) + 2 * S(O2) = 1 * 186.3 J/K·mol + 2 * 205.0 J/K·mol = 186.3 + 410.0 = 596.3 J/K·mol

Now, we can calculate the entropy change (ΔS):

ΔS = ΣnS(products) - ΣnS(reactants) = 353.6 J/K·mol - 596.3 J/K·mol = -242.7 J/K·mol

The entropy change for the combustion of methane at standard conditions is -242.7 J/K·mol.
